citation.article-title: Agreia bicolorata gen. nov., sp. nov., to accommodate actinobacteria isolated from narrow reed grass infected by the nematode Heteroanguina graminophila
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Agreia bicolorata sp. nov.
Agreia bicolorata (bi.co.lo.ra.ta. M.L. n. bis two; M.L. adj. coloratum coloured; M.L. fem. adj. bicolorata two-coloured)
General morphological, chemotaxonomic and growth characteristics are as given above in the genus description.
Colonies are yellow-orange to orange in young cultures and red-orange to brown-orange with age, semi-fluid or fluid.
Abundant capsule is usually formed.
Cells are irregular rods (0.4-0.5x1.2-2.5 μm) that are weakly motile.
In older cultures, shorter irregular rods predominate as single cells ; pairs or short chains with diphtheroid arrangements may be present.
A marked rod-coccus growth cycle does not occur.
Mesophilic.
Thermal optimum for growth is 24-26°C; growth occurs at 37°C.
Cell wall peptidoglycan is of the B-type and contains DAB, ornithine, alanine, glycine and glutamate plus hydroxyglutamate (1:1:2:2:2 molar ratio).
Cell wall sugars are rhamnose, mannose and fucose.
DNA G­C content is about 67.0 mol%.
A wide range of carbohydrate and organic acids are used for growth; utilization of succinate, acetate and propionate varied in the strains.
Only a few amino acids are utilized as a source of nitrogen.
H2S is weakly produced.
Voges-Proskauer test is positive and methyl red test is negative.
No growth with 6% NaCl.
Strains are susceptible to 10 μg ml-1 ampicillin, doxycycline, gentamicin, penicillin, rifampicin and tetracycline, but tolerate the same concentration of neomycin and streptomycin.
Isolated from leaf galls on Calamagrostis neglecta, induced by the plant-parasitic nematode Heteroanguina graminophila (Moscow region, Russia).
Type strain is VKMAc-1804T (=UCMAc-620T), deposited in the All-Russian collection of Microorganisms (VKM) and Ukrainian Collection of Microorganisms (UCM).
